questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with signs of obstructive jaundice. Which of the following tests would be considered the initial imaging modality in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ultrasound Transabdominal ultrasonography (US) is the initial imaging modality of choice as it is accurate, readily available, inexpensive, and quick to perform. For the patient who presents with obstructive jaundice, ultrasonography is particularly helpful because it can identify intra- and extrahepatic biliary dilatation and often the level of obstruction .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Percutaneous cholangiography is an invasive technique in which the bile ducts are cannulated percutaneously. In general, if a malignant stricture at the level of the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts or higher is suspected in a jaundiced patient, a PTC is preferred. It is done by China/Okuda needle. Option: B . Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography remains widely used as both a diagnostic and a therapeutic modality and provides excellent images of the ductal anatomy and can identify causes of obstruction such as calculi or malignant strictures. While the widespread availability of ultrasound and MRCP has reduced their diagnostic use, ERCP still plays a vital role in assessing a patient with obstructive jaundice. In this group of patients, it is instrumental in determining the cause and level of obstruction. Option:D Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography is a noninvasive modality that provides excellent gallbladder and biliary system imaging. Images of the biliary tree demonstrating ductal obstruction, strictures, or other intraductal abnormalities can be obtained. T2 MRI does it.

questions.correct_answer: C. Plain X-ray is useful for calcification, seen in 80% of gallstones.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Plain X-ray is useful for calcification, seen in 80% of gallstones. Plain X-ray in biliary imaging is an obsolete investigation, as only 10% of gallstones are radio-opaque . This is in contrast to renal stones where 90 percent are radio-opaque.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with a two-day history of nausea and vomiting following meals. Associated symptoms included bloating, mild epigastric discomfort, anorexia, and choluria. Physical examination was notable for tachycardia and icteric sclera. Which of the following test is accurate in imaging the bile duct and detecting the presence of choledocholithiasis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) utilizes a specially designed endoscope with an ultrasound transducer at its tip, allowing the gastroenterologist to visualize the liver and biliary tree from within the stomach and duodenum. It is accurate in imaging the bile duct and detecting the presence of choledocholithiasis. MRCP also shows choledocholithiasis with high sensitivity. However, tiny stones may be difficult to pick up on MRCP, and EUS can be used in such cases.

Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is a diagnostic procedure. It involves using an endoscope with an ultrasound transducer at its tip. EUS allows obtaining high-resolution images of the liver and biliary tree from within the stomach and duodenum. EUS is accurate in detecting choledocholithiasis. EUS is also valuable for diagnosing and staging pancreatic and periampullary cancers. Biopsies can be obtained from suspicious areas for cytological and histological analysis. EUS is a valuable tool in diagnosing and managing various gastrointestinal disorders.

questions.correct_answer: C. Preoperative cholangiography is routinely done in cholecystectomy.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Preoperative cholangiography is routinely done in cholecystectomy. A preoperative cholangiogram is not routinely done in cholecystectomy. Those who routinely do so to delineate the anatomy of the biliary tree, as in almost 20%, there is an anatomical variation. It is also done to exclude unsuspected stones in the CBD. Similarly, the graham Cole test (oral cholecystography) has only limited indication nowadays and is historically significant.

MRCP Images comparable to those obtained using ERCP or PTC can be achieved non-invasively without the potential complications of either technique. Option: D. Once the CBD is explored for stones, laparoscopically or by open method, operative biliary endoscopy in the form of choledochoscopy should be carried out to ensure all stones have been removed.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with intermittent pain in the right hypochondrium for a week. Physical examination revealed no local tenderness. Liver function parameters were normal. Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen revealed two cystic formations in the gallbladder (GB) fossa with no distinct visualization of the cystic duct. No GB wall thickening was noted, thus ruling out GB diverticula. A differential diagnosis of choledochal cyst and duplicated GB was given. Which of the following would be the investigation of choice in diagnosing choledochal cysts?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRCP Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography is a noninvasive modality that provides excellent gallbladder and biliary system imaging. Images of the biliary tree demonstrating ductal obstruction, strictures, or other intraductal abnormalities can be obtained. It is the investigation of choice for choledocholithiasis, Cholangitis, CBD status, Biliary stricture, Biliary leak, and Choledochal cyst. Images comparable to those obtained using ERCP or PTC can be achieved non-invasively without the potential complications of either technique. Earlier, Alonso-led classification was used for choledochal cysts. However, now, today classification is used globally.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man complained of abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound indicated acute cholecystitis and a single, extremely large pear-shaped gallstone. Which of the following investigations can be used as a treatment modality in treating gallstones?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ERCP Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography remains widely used as both a diagnostic and a therapeutic modality and provides excellent images of the ductal anatomy and can identify causes of obstruction such as calculi or malignant strictures. Therapeutic interventions such as stone removal or stent placement to relieve the block can be performed. Thus, ERCP has evolved into a mainly therapeutic rather than a diagnostic technique. Sphincterotomy is done at 11 o'clock when negotiating the scope inside the CBD

Diagnosis of cholelithiasis : The first test is usually an abdominal ultrasound (USG) , which can detect gallstones in the gallbladder and also estimate the diameter of the common bile duct (CBD). A dilated CBD ( >8 mm in diameter ) in a patient with gallstones, jaundice, and biliary pain highly suggests choledocholithiasis . Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is a noninvasive imaging test that provides excellent anatomical detail and has a sensitivity and specificity of 95% and 98%, respectively, for detecting CBD stones. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic test of choice for patients suspected of having gallstones or CBD stones.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presented with a 3 weeks history of obstructive jaundice. Liver and kidney function analyses, and routine blood tests were conducted upon admission; and hepatic bilirubin levels were higher than normal. Abdominal computed tomography (CT) showed pancreatic cancer, as well as dilation of the intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts. The patient was at an advanced disease stage and refused to undergo surgical resection. Which of the following can be done to decompress the biliary obstruction non-surgically?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography can be useful for patients with the intrahepatic biliary disease or in whom ERCP is not technically feasible; PTC can decompress biliary obstruction and stent obstructions nonoperatively and can provide anatomic information for biliary reconstruction. The disadvantage of PTC is that it is associated with higher sepsis rates
